text: I think that that with Syria there was a
there was a feeling at the beginning
that Assad would simply go if we call
the problem to go but then what happened
was that Iran activated his blur on the
ground to support Assad and then Russia
of course has come in very strongly on
the SATs side and as it has gone on so
the opposition have fractured the
extremist groups have had a vacuum that
they can fill and and basing themselves
in in Raqqa in Syria then they created
this this territory in Syria and Iraq
that they hold I think we've got to know
now that even if we thought we could
stay out of Syria we can't because our
own interests are dramatically involved
and what the Paris attacks show us is
that these groups if they're given this
opportunity to to gain strength they are
in the end going to come to the west
come to to Europe even to the United
States of America and and target us
there so I think what is important is
that we see Syria as part of this wider
battle against extremism and even though
it's very difficult and I know this how
we make the decisions of engagement in
this struggle I think we have to be
engaged right I mean part of the reason
obviously that there is so much
reluctance here in Washington to have
got engaged on the part of President
Obama was because of the mess left
behind by the invasion of Iraq you've
said look Iraq showed us that you remove
one dictator strong man in the Middle
East and you get created with a whole
you've given me a whole new load of
problems I mean it's you can understand
why the world is reluctant right
absolutely I can understand that but one
thing I think is very important to
recognize is that we've had our
experience in Afghanistan and Iraq we've
also got our experience now in Libya and
in Syria and the Arab Spring and what
that shows is that even if we may say
and you often hear this in the West look
maybe it's just better if we deal with
the dictator in the end I'm afraid those
countries out in that region the young
populations who are frustrated deprived
of opportunity they're not going to
tolerate that so inevitably we are going
to have to be involved and the question
is how do we get involved most sensibly
and the one benefit we have
day in the difference frankly from the
time I was in office is that you have
allies today in the Arab and Muslim
world right but they're not doing very
much they're doing less in terms of
airstrikes now than they were at the
beginning of this well they actually are
doing quite a lot on the on the ground
as well by the way I mean some of the
Gulf countries are significantly
involved in that they're very important
I mean even though what is happening in
Yemen is extremely difficult it is very
important at the same time that they're
prepared to get engaged there because
that is also potentially a huge problem
for the region and the wider world but
the point that I'm making is that where
as post 9/11 a lot of countries in the
region tend to think well this is your
problem you're dealing with it today all
of those countries got their own issues
of extremism their own problems that
they're there they're fighting and they
they see the opportunity now for an
alliance and we have the opportunity for
an alliance that wasn't there before
